DOC.brief_summary: The number of people seeking treatment for marijuana-related problems is on the rise, yet there is no currently accepted medication proven to help them quit. Frequent marijuana users have reported that they have trouble sleeping when they try to quit, and that the loss of sleep can lead to relapse. This research is designed to measure the severity of sleep problems in people as they are trying to quit heavy use of marijuana, and to investigate whether extended-release zolpidem (Ambien CRÂ®) can improve quit rates among people trying to stop using marijuana.
DOC.brief_title: The Role of Sleep in the Treatment of Cannabis Use Disorders
DOC.criteria: 1. Age 1855 years. 2. Recent problematic use of cannabis 3. Cannabis use impacts sleep 1. Dependent on drugs other than cannabis or nicotine, or current Axis I psychiatric disorder 2. Moderate sleep apnea or periodic limb movement disorder 3. Pregnant, breast feeding, or planning to become pregnant within the next 3 months 4. Current condition associated with severe cognitive/social impairment 5. Allergy to any ingredient in extendedrelease zolpidem or prior adverse reaction to zolpidem 6. Current use of drugs that affect metabolism via cytochrome P450 or current illness resulting in severe hepatic impairment 7. Current use of hypnotic medications
